body_content.explanation: a substance, especially when you do not know or say exactly what it is:
examples: There's sticky stuff all over the chair.
What's this black stuff?
He drinks gallons of tea - he loves the stuff.

body_content.explanation: things that someone says or does, when you are referring to them in a general way without saying exactly what they are:
examples: All that stuff she has been saying about Lee is just not true.
We did some really interesting stuff today.
I have to go now - I've got stuff to do.
I've read all her books - I really like her stuff.

body_content.explanation: someone's possessions or things that they take somewhere with them:
examples: We'll have to carry all our camping stuff.
Do you want help bringing your stuff in from the van?
We can't move to a smaller place - we've got too much stuff.

body_content.explanation: used to refer to more things of a similar kind to ones you have mentioned, when you do not say exactly what they are:
examples: This is the drawer where I keep paper and envelopes and stuff.
The classrooms all have computers and interactive whiteboards and stuff.
I was embarrassed because he wanted to talk about love and stuff.
Avery had great stuff, total command of all three of his pitches.
An interview is a chance to show your stuff.

body_content.explanation: to completely fill a container with something:
examples: Stuff the pillow and then sew up the final seam.
Under her bed, they found a bag stuffed with money.

body_content.explanation: to push something into a small space, often quickly or in a careless way:
examples: This suitcase is absolutely full - I can't stuff another thing into it.

body_content.explanation: to fill the body of a dead animal with special material so that it looks as if it is still alive
(of a man) to have sex with a woman

examples: Stuff the turkey, then put it into a pre-heated oven.
They'd been stuffing themselves with snacks all afternoon, so they didn't want any dinner.
